title: Consider suggesting to folks that they wanted a `Vec` when they passed a slice

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur.
-->

Given the following code: <!-- Please provide a link to play.rust-lang.org -->

```rust
fn manipulate_vec(v: &[&str]) {
    v.retain(|i| i.starts_with("h"))
}

fn main() {
    let v = vec!["hello", "goodbyte"];
    manipulate_vec(&v); 
    println!("{:?}", v);
}
```

[playground link](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=1b4320d5427afea9ab3e55d18a66ab75)

The current output is:

```
error[E0599]: no method named `retain` found for reference `&[&str]` in the current scope
 --> src/main.rs:2:7
  |
2 |     v.retain(|i| i.starts_with("h"))
  |       ^^^^^^ method not found in `&[&str]`

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0599`.
error: could not compile `playground` due to previous error
```

<!-- The following is not always necessary. -->
This is absolutely right, but maybe we can be more helpful here?

```
error[E0599]: no method named `retain` found for reference `&[&str]` in the current scope
 --> src/main.rs:2:7
  |
2 |     v.retain(|i| i.starts_with("h"))
  |       ^^^^^^ method not found in `&[&str]`

  |
  | Vec has a method called 'retain'. Perhaps you meant for your method to take a Vec instead
  | of a slice?
1 |     fn manipulate_vec(v: &[&str]) {
  |                          ^^^^^^^
  |          consider: fn manipulate_vec(v: &mut Vec<&str>) {

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0599`.
error: could not compile `playground` due to previous error
```

A (relative) Rust newbie hit this whilst attempting Advent of Code this year and it wasn't obvious to them what they were doing wrong. I don't know how easy it would be to add a special diagnostic here (especially given there are mut-vs-non-mut issues) and whether `Vec` is sufficiently special to justify it, but I thought I'd pass the idea on.

The Rust newbie keeps saying how great Rust error messages are 👍
